citeinfo.title: Data release: Daily surface temperatures for 185,549 lakes in the Contiguous United States estimated using deep learning (1980-2020)
citeinfo.geoform: Two comma-delimited files and six NetCDF files

citeinfo.title: Daily surface temperatures for 185,549 lakes in the Conterminous United States estimated using deep learning (1980-2020)

descript.abstract: The data release of daily lake surface temperatures comprises 185,549 lakes across the continental United States from 1980 to 2020 that are generated using an entity-aware long short-term memory deep learning model. In-situ measurements used for model training spanned a subset of 12,227 lakes. Model training was optimized for prediction on unmonitored lakes through a cross validation framework. Median per-lake estimated error found through cross validation on lakes with in-situ surface temperature observations was 1.24 °C. The generated dataset will be beneficial for a wide range of applications including estimations of thermal habitats and the impacts of climate change on inland lakes.
descript.purpose: This dataset is well suited as a research complement to the fields of fisheries biology, limnology, climate change science, and aquatic invasive species research. The temperature predictions included here can be inputs to other models where water temperature is required.

spdom.descgeog: NetCDF and delimited files that contain predictions, weather data, and metadata for 185,549 lakes in the Contiguous U.S.

place.placekt: Department of Commerce, 1995, Countries, Dependencies, Areas of Special Sovereignty, and Their Principal Administrative Divisions, Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS) 10-4, Washington, D.C., National Institute of Standards and Technology

U.S. Department of Commerce, 1987, Codes for the identification of the States, the District of Columbia and the outlying areas of the United States, and associated areas (Federal Information Processing Standard 5-2): Washington, D. C., NIST

idinfo.useconst: These data are open access usable via creative commons as long as original data providers are acknowledged
idinfo.datacred: This study was funded by the Department of the Interior Midwest Climate Adaptation Science Center. This research used resources of the Core Science Analytics and Synthesis Advanced Research Computing program at the U.S. Geological Survey.
idinfo.native: Multiple computer systems were used to generate these data, including linux, OSX. The open source languages R and Python were used on all systems.

citeinfo.title: Towards learning universal, regional, and local hydrological behaviors via machine learning applied to large-sample datasets
The multi-institution North American Land Data Assimilation System (NLDAS): Utilizing multiple GCIP products and partners in a continental distributed hydrological modeling system
elevatr: Access Elevation Data from Various APIs
Simple Features for R: Standardized Support for Spatial Vector Data
The Distribution and Prediction of Summer Near-Surface Water Temperatures in Lakes of the Coterminous United States and Southern Canada

attracc.attraccr: No formal attribute accuracy tests were conducted for spatial data. For model prediction, accuracy and bias was assessed. See Willard et al. 2022 for methodological details and results of this assessment.

horizpa.horizpar: A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the dataset was not conducted.

vertacc.vertaccr: A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the dataset was not conducted.

procstep.procdesc: This dataset was generated using the methodology explained in the peer-reviewed paper Willard et al. 2022. Details within that paper describe how models were built and other data were assembled. Modeling environment information is captured below: This dataset was generated using open source tools available in the R programming language (R version 4.1.0 (2021-05-18)). The computing platform for generating data and metadata was x86_64-apple-darwin17.0. R packages loaded into this environment: ncdf4, version: 1.17; remake, version: 0.3.0; viridis, version: 0.6.1; viridisLite, version: 0.4.0; ncdfgeom, version: 1.1.2; glmtools, version: 0.15.0; rLakeAnalyzer, version: 1.11.4.1; GLMr, version: 3.1.16; whisker, version: 0.4; sf, version: 1.0-2; lwgeom, version: 0.2-6; rgdal, version: 1.5-23; sp, version: 1.4-5; yaml, version: 2.2.1; sbtools, version: 1.1.15; scipiper, version: 0.0.24; meddle, version: 0.0.16; mapdata, version: 2.3.0; maps, version: 3.3.0; forcats, version: 0.5.1; readr, version: 1.4.0; ggplot2, version: 3.3.4; tidyverse, version: 1.3.1; ffanalytics, version: 2.0.10.0001; xml2, version: 1.3.2; httr, version: 1.4.2; stringr, version: 1.4.0; tidyr, version: 1.1.3; tibble, version: 3.1.4; dplyr, version: 1.0.7; purrr, version: 0.3.4; rvest, version: 1.0.1. This dataset was generated using open source tools available in the Python programming language (Python version 3.6.10) with K40 GPUs with CUDA version 11.4. enttyp.enttypd: A NetCDF file containing daily surface water temperature predictions for 62,560 U.S. lakes located between 24°N to 53°N and -98°E to -126°E from 1980-2020. Predictions were made using the EA-LSTM model as described in Kratzert et al., (2019) and applied to lake prediction in Willard et al., (2021).

attr.attrdef: Lake identification number for this dataset. Is the Prmnn_I prefixed with source, as "nhdhr_{Prmnn_I}".
Predicted daily lake surface temperature from the entity-aware long short term memory (EA-LSTM) network model
attr.attrdefs: This release; Willard et al., 2022; Kratzert et al., 2019

attr.attrdef: Latitude of lake centroid, calculated from the national hydrography dataset polygons using the st_centroid function in the sf R package.
Longitude of lake centroid, calculated from the national hydrography dataset polygons using the st_centroid function in the sf R package.
Approximate elevation of lake surface above sea level as estimated by the elevatr R package using the centroid of the lake.
date of prediction

enttyp.enttypd: A NetCDF file containing daily surface water temperature predictions for 59,476 U.S. lakes located between 40°N to 53°N and -67°E to -98°E from 1980-2020. Predictions were made using the EA-LSTM model as described in Kratzert et al., (2019) and applied to lake prediction in Willard et al., (2021).

attr.attrdef: Lake identification number for this dataset. Is the Prmnn_I prefixed with source, as "nhdhr_{Prmnn_I}".
Predicted daily lake surface temperature from the entity-aware long short term memory (EA-LSTM) network model
attr.attrdefs: This release; Willard et al., 2022; Kratzert et al., 2019

attr.attrdef: Latitude of lake centroid, calculated from the national hydrography dataset polygons using the st_centroid function in the sf R package.
Longitude of lake centroid, calculated from the national hydrography dataset polygons using the st_centroid function in the sf R package.
Approximate elevation of lake surface above sea level as estimated by the elevatr R package using the centroid of the lake.
date of prediction

enttyp.enttypd: A NetCDF file containing daily surface water temperature predictions for 63,513 U.S. lakes located between 24°N to 40°N and -67°E to -98°E from 1980-2020. Predictions were made using the EA-LSTM model as described in Kratzert et al., (2019) and applied to lake prediction in Willard et al., (2021).

attr.attrdef: Lake identification number for this dataset. Is the Prmnn_I prefixed with source, as "nhdhr_{Prmnn_I}".
Predicted daily lake surface temperature from the entity-aware long short term memory (EA-LSTM) network model
attr.attrdefs: This release; Willard et al., 2022; Kratzert et al., 2019

attr.attrdef: Latitude of lake centroid, calculated from the national hydrography dataset polygons using the st_centroid function in the sf R package.
Longitude of lake centroid, calculated from the national hydrography dataset polygons using the st_centroid function in the sf R package.
Approximate elevation of lake surface above sea level as estimated by the elevatr R package using the centroid of the lake.
date of prediction

enttyp.enttypd: A NetCDF file containing daily meteorological conditions for 13,661 grid cells that contained lakes between 24°N to 53°N and -98°E to -126°E from 1980-2020. Meteorological conditions are daily averages of hourly estimates. See lake_metadata.csv to match grid locations (weather_id) to the associated lake site_id (some grid cells apply to multiple lakes).

attr.attrdef: Identifier for meteorological data from the NLDAS data grid, where the x (longitude) and y (latitude) specify cell indices for the dataset. Format of this identifier is "nldas_x{x-index}_y{y-index}".
longwave radiation flux downwards
shortwave radiation flux downwards
2-m above ground temperature
10-m above ground zonal wind speed
10-m above ground meridional wind speed
latitude of grid cell centroid
latitude of grid cell centroid
date of prediction

enttyp.enttypd: A NetCDF file containing daily meteorological conditions for 8,278 grid cells that contained lakes between 40°N to 53°N and -67°E to -98°E from 1980-2020. Meteorological conditions are daily averages of hourly estimates. See lake_metadata.csv to match grid locations (weather_id) to the associated lake site_id (some grid cells apply to multiple lakes).

attr.attrdef: Identifier for meteorological data from the NLDAS data grid, where the x (longitude) and y (latitude) specify cell indices for the dataset. Format of this identifier is "nldas_x{x-index}_y{y-index}".

shortwave radiation flux downwards
2-m above ground temperature
10-m above ground zonal wind speed
10-m above ground meridional wind speed

Meteorological conditions are daily averages of hourly estimates. See lake_metadata.csv to match grid locations (weather_id) to the associated lake site_id (some grid cells apply to multiple lakes).

attr.attrdef: Identifier for meteorological data from the NLDAS data grid, where the x (longitude) and y (latitude) specify cell indices for the dataset. Format of this identifier is "nldas_x{x-index}_y{y-index}".

enttyp.enttypd: Select metadata for the 185,549 lakes included in this study

attr.attrdef: Lake identification number for this dataset. It is the Prmnn_I from NHD high-res prefixed with source, as "nhdhr_{Prmnn_I}". The ids have a mix of characters and some can include special characters, such as "{" and "}".
Identifier for meteorological data from the NLDAS data grid, where the x (longitude) and y (latitude) specify cell indices for the dataset. Format of this identifier is "nldas_x{x-index}_y{y-index}".
Number of unique dates with surface water temperature observations for this lake
The approximate surface area of the lake
Approximate elevation of lake surface above sea level as estimated by the elevatr R package using the centroid of the lake
Longitude of lake centroid, calculated from the national hydrography dataset polygons using the st_centroid function in the sf R package.
Latitude of lake centroid, calculated from the national hydrography dataset polygons using the st_centroid function in the sf R package.
longitude of NLDAS cell centroid used to as input for EA-LSTM and LM models. Centroid was calculated using the st_centroid function in the sf R package.
latitude of NLDAS cell centroid used to as input for EA-LSTM and LM models. Centroid was calculated using the st_centroid function in the sf R package.
Root-mean square error (RMSE; in degrees C) of the entity-aware long short term memory (EA-LSTM) surface water temperature predictions. RMSE is estimated from performance using cross-fold validation.

Root-mean square error (RMSE; in degrees C) of the linear model (LM) surface water temperature predictions. RMSE is estimated from performance using cross-fold validation. This LM used the same structure and inputs as Bachmann et al., (2019) but was re-trained and re-evaluated using the lake surface water temperature observations included in this data release. Contrary to other RMSE values reported here, these lake-specific estimates of model performance were calculated with data only from June-September.
attr.attrdefs: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Root-mean-square_deviation; Willard et al., 2022; Bachmann et al., 2019

attr.attrdef: Root-mean square error (RMSE; in degrees C) of the surface mixed-layer of the noon UTC-5 grid-representation of lakes in the ERA5 global reanalysis which used the FLake parametrization for lake simulations.
attr.attrdefs: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Root-mean-square_deviation; Willard et al., 2022; Hersbach et al., 2020

attr.attrdef: Numeric identifier for which of the 16 k-means clusters of lakes based on latitude, longitude, and surface area.
Numeric identifier for which of the 5 equal groups of lakes used for nested cross validation. Each cluster (cluster_id) of lakes is equally divided among the 5 fold_ids.
The latitude and longitude range that this lake fits into. Used for determining file pattern for associated "prediction" or "weather" NetCDF files.
The the two digit group this lake fits into. Used for determining file pattern for associated "prediction" or "weather" NetCDF files.

enttyp.enttypd: Observed and predicted surface water temperature for 12,227 lakes. Predictions for 306,553 unique lake-days from the EA-LSTM (Willard et al., 2021) model and 303,579 from the ERA5 FLake model (Hersbach et al., 2020) matched to observations (ERA5 FLake outputs for 70 near-coastal lakes are "NA"). 188,886 predictions from the Bachmann et al. (2019) model span the months of June-September (other dates are "NA").

attr.attrdef: Lake identification number for this dataset. It is the Prmnn_I from NHD high-res prefixed with source, as "nhdhr_{Prmnn_I}". The ids have a mix of characters and some can include special characters, such as "{" and "}".
date of prediction or observation
Predicted surface temperature from the EA-LSTM model (Willard et al., 2021; Kratzert et al., 2019)
Predicted surface temperature from the Bachmann linear model (Bachmann et al., 2019)
Predicted surface temperature from the ERA5 FLake model (Hersbach et al., 2020)
Predicted surface temperature from the ERA5 FLake model (Hersbach et al., 2020) with simple offset (+3.31°C; Willard et al., 2022) applied for the purpose of removing a cold bias.
Observed surface temperature (Willard et al., 2022)
Data source name from monitoring group (Willard et al., 2022)
attr.attrdefs: Data source name from monitoring group; "unresolved" used when missing.

cntaddr.address: Denver Federal Center, Building 810, Mail Stop 302

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty.
